lessons.title: What is Mass?
content: ## Understanding Mass
Mass is the amount of matter (stuff) in an object. Everything around you has mass - your desk, your pencil, even the air you breathe!
### Why Mass Matters in Space
In space, mass is super important because:
- Objects with more mass have stronger gravity
- Mass determines whether something can become a star
- The mass of an object affects its color and temperature
### Measuring Cosmic Mass
Scientists measure the mass of space objects by comparing them to our Sun:
- **Solar Mass (M☉)**: The mass of our Sun
- Earth = 0.000003 M☉ (very tiny compared to the Sun!)
- Jupiter = 0.001 M☉ (1000 times less than the Sun)
**Try it yourself:** Move the slider to see objects of different masses!

lessons.title: Planets: The Lightweights
content: ## What Makes a Planet?
Planets are objects that orbit stars. They're much smaller than stars and don't make their own light.
### Types of Planets
**Rocky Planets** (like Earth and Mars):
- Very small mass (less than 0.00001 M☉)
- Made of rock and metal
- Have solid surfaces you could walk on
**Gas Giants** (like Jupiter and Saturn):
- Bigger mass (around 0.001 M☉)
- Made mostly of gas
- No solid surface - you'd fall right through!
### Why Planets Don't Shine
Planets don't have enough mass to create fusion in their cores. That's why they don't glow like stars - they only reflect light from their star!
**Activity:** Set the mass to 0.000003 (Earth) and then to 0.001 (Jupiter). Notice the difference!

lessons.title: Brown Dwarfs: Failed Stars
content: ## What is a Brown Dwarf?
Brown dwarfs are sometimes called "failed stars." They're bigger than planets but smaller than stars.
### The In-Between Objects
Brown dwarfs have a mass between 0.013 and 0.08 M☉. That's:
- About 13 to 80 times the mass of Jupiter
- Not quite enough mass to be a real star
- Too much mass to be a planet
### Why They Failed
To be a real star, you need enough mass to start fusion (combining atoms to make energy). Brown dwarfs almost made it, but they're just a bit too small!
They glow a little bit from leftover heat from when they formed, but they get cooler and dimmer over time.
**Fun fact:** Brown dwarfs can be the same size as Jupiter, but they're much heavier (more mass in the same space)!

lessons.title: Stars: The Bright Giants
content: ## What Makes a Star Shine?
Stars are giant balls of hot, glowing gas. They make their own light through a process called fusion!
### The Mass Requirement
To be a star, an object needs at least 0.08 M☉ (about 80 times Jupiter's mass). With this much mass, the core gets so hot and squeezed that fusion starts!
### Different Star Sizes
- The smallest, coolest stars
- Glow red or orange
- Live for trillions of years!
**Sun-like Stars** (0.45 - 8 M☉):
- Medium-sized stars (like our Sun)
- Glow yellow or white
- Live for billions of years
**Massive Stars** (8+ M☉):
- The biggest, hottest stars
- Glow blue-white
- Live only millions of years (they burn fast!)
**Remember:** More massive stars burn brighter but die faster!

lessons.title: Black Holes: Where Mass Wins
content: ## The Ultimate Gravity Trap
Black holes are the strangest objects in space. They have SO much mass packed into a tiny space that nothing can escape - not even light!
### How Black Holes Form
When a massive star (more than 20 M☉) runs out of fuel, it collapses and creates a black hole. All that mass gets squeezed into an incredibly small point!
### Why They're Black
Black holes have such strong gravity that even light can't escape. That's why they look completely black - no light comes out!
### The Accretion Disk
Matter falling into a black hole forms a spinning disk around it called an accretion disk. This disk gets so hot that it glows brightly - even though the black hole itself is dark!
**Amazing fact:** If you could put all of Earth's mass into a ball the size of a marble, it would be a black hole!
**Try it:** Set the mass to 10 M☉ to see a black hole with its glowing accretion disk!
